ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with congenital sensorineural hearing loss and delayed speech/language development. Most common syndromic cause of hearing loss.
Presents with sensorineural hearing loss in ~20% of cases, which can lead to speech delays. Additional features like pigmentary abnormalities would help confirm.
Higher frequency of hearing loss (~50%) compared to Type 1, leading to speech delays. Lacks dystopia canthorum seen in Type 1.
Congenital profound sensorineural hearing loss with speech delays. Progressive retinitis pigmentosa typically manifests later in childhood.
Congenital profound bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with speech delays. Associated with long QT syndrome - ECG screening would be critical.
Can present with hearing loss and developmental delays. Typically has multiple congenital anomalies that would be apparent.
Sensorineural, conductive, or mixed hearing loss with speech delays. Often has branchial and renal anomalies.
Progressive sensorineural hearing loss can occur, though typically later onset. Renal involvement would be expected.
